text: [Music]
well I have a personal philosophy but I
I'm always trying to modify it I think
part of the the interesting uh thing
about being a historian is that you want
to be proved wrong I mean I want to see
some exception to a rule that I thought
I believed uh because that's the
revelatory moment uh I I have no vested
interest in being consistent uh and if I
think exactly the same 20 years from now
as I think now the intervening 20 years
will have been a disappointment to me if
if I felt that my objective was just to
verify my philosophy I would give up
tomorrow it's actually to falsify it so
let's let's start with what the
philosophy is I I was brought up uh and
remain an
atheist but to to be brought up an
atheist is very different from lapsing
from religious Faith I've never had any
religious faith I have however a
profound belief that as a basis for
ethical conduct The Ten Commandments are
pretty good and that actually uh the
monotheisms and particularly
Christianity offer a really quite good
guide to how to live well by well I mean
to live morally it's very hard for an
atheist to invent from first principles
a good ethical basis uh for Behavior
because actually in the Natural State
human beings don't behave well they're
quite strongly tempted to behave badly
and we're evolved in ways that uh that
actually encourage bad
behavior we're designed to kill
strangers uh we're designed in fact to
to to steal and so it's very important
that there should be an ethical
framework within which we live and my
dilemma is that I don't really believe
in any Divine policeman uh or any
afterlife payoffs but I do believe that
we should live well we should obey some
moral code that we're not likely to
invent for ourselves so beyond that
there are a number of other important
things that I believe in I think I uh
believe in uh the truth of darwinian uh
Evolution I think I'm strongly attracted
and believe in Adam Smith's vision of
the free market as a superior motive uh
of economic organization uh I'm strongly
persuaded by uh uh chaos theory about
the nature of the natural world and the
nonlinearities that are out there to
spoil the Newtonian party but I still
subscribe to Newton's Laws of Motion I
believe in all of these things and
they're my working assumptions because
as I said I'm the son of scientists but
not a scientist myself I can't challenge
much of that I I guess I take it on
trust
but it does seem to me to hang together
reasonably well and for an historian it
provides uh enough of a framework enough
of a framework to understand the natural
world uh to enable me to focus on what I
am interested in which is the way that
humans behave within that natural world
under the constraints that it imposes on
them so those are the things I believe
in what I don't have strong views about
uh are the motivations of human beings
themselves uh Human Nature nature seems
to me to be the stuff of historical
study and although I'm probably
instinctively a Hoban in other words I
think that the state of nature is pretty
ugly and civilization is all about
trying to re our natural impulses in I'm
prepared to be argued out of that in
other words if somebody can persuade me
that in fact human beings innately have
a preference for order and social
cooperation rather than killing one
another and that they're killing one
another is the exception rather than the
norm then I will certainly listen uh and
and then be prepared to be convinced
[Music]
